rsbNotes.title: 1 Kings 11:1
rsbNotes.text: 11:1 loved many foreign women. Whereas in the first part of his reign, “Solomon loved the Lord, walking in the statutes of David his father” (3:3), he later “loved many foreign women.” Diplomatic marriages between the dynasties of various kingdoms were common in the ancient Near East as a means of ratifying treaties, but the multiplication of royal wives is forbidden in Deut. 17:17. Moreover, there were prohibitions against marrying foreign wives in the land Israel was to possess (Ex. 34:16; Deut. 7:1–4; Josh. 23:12, 13).

rsbNotes.title: 1 Kings 11:2
rsbNotes.text: 11:2 turn away your heart. The phrase alludes to the warning of Deut. 7:4.

rsbNotes.title: 1 Kings 11:4
rsbNotes.text: 11:4 as was the heart of David his father. David is consistently presented as a model king (3:14; 9:4; 14:8; 15:3; 2 Kin. 8:19; 22:2). He was not without sins (2 Sam. 11; 12; 24:1–15; 1 Kin. 15:5), but when he sinned, his repentance was exemplary (2 Sam. 12:16, 17; 24:10–17). David’s devotion to God was unparalleled.

rsbNotes.title: 1 Kings 11:5
rsbNotes.text:
11:5 Ashtoreth. The Phoenician goddess of love and fertility, called Astarte by the Greeks (cf. Judg. 2:13; 2 Kin. 23:13).

Milcom. Or Molech. He was the national god of the Ammonites.

rsbNotes.title: 1 Kings 11:6
rsbNotes.text: 11:6 Solomon did what was evil. Solomon’s many sins violated fundamental principles of Israelite religion: multiplying wives (v. 1 note), worshiping other gods (Ex. 20:3, 5), and building sanctuaries for the foreign gods (vv. 7, 8; Ex. 20:4).

rsbNotes.title: 1 Kings 11:7
rsbNotes.text: 11:7 Chemosh. He was the national god of the Moabites (2 Kin. 3:26, 27). See “Syncretism and Idolatry” at Hos. 2:13.

rsbNotes.title: 1 Kings 11:10
rsbNotes.text: 11:10 after other gods. See 3:14; 9:6–9.

rsbNotes.title: 1 Kings 11:11
rsbNotes.text: 11:11 tear the kingdom from you. See vv. 29–39.

rsbNotes.title: 1 Kings 11:12
rsbNotes.text: 11:12 I will not do it in your days. God’s great love for David causes Him to temper His judgment on Solomon in two respects: first, God postpones the division until the reign of Solomon’s son; and second, God does not remove the entire kingdom from the Davidic dynasty (v. 13).

rsbNotes.title: 1 Kings 11:13
rsbNotes.text:
11:13 one tribe. This probably refers to Judah (12:20; 2 Kin. 17:18). If Judah is already understood without being mentioned, another tribe is meant, such as Benjamin (12:21) or Simeon.

for the sake of Jerusalem. Jerusalem was God’s chosen city, the site of Israel’s central sanctuary anticipated in Deut. 12 and constructed by Solomon. Jerusalem is a central symbol of God’s love for His people and the communion between God and His people throughout the Bible (Ps. 68:29; 122:2–6; 135:21; 137:5–7; Is. 62:1; Dan. 9:25; Rev. 3:12; 21:2, 10).

rsbNotes.title: 1 Kings 11:15
rsbNotes.text: 11:15 when David was in Edom. See 2 Sam. 8:14. An earlier victory by Joab is reversed, as Hadad returns from exile in Egypt and successfully rebels against Solomon (v. 25).

rsbNotes.title: 1 Kings 11:18
rsbNotes.text:
11:18 from Midian. The Midianites lived east of Moab and Edom.

Paran. This area was in the Sinai peninsula southeast of Kadesh.

gave him a house. Taking notice of the emerging power of David, Pharaoh was ready to shelter David’s foes in the hope that one day they would curtail Israel’s power (v. 21). Ancient treaties forbid providing asylum to political rebels.

rsbNotes.title: 1 Kings 11:22
rsbNotes.text: 11:22 Only let me depart. Following David’s death, Hadad wanted to return to his own land, despite the Pharaoh’s objections, probably because he wanted to liberate it from Israelite domination (v. 25).

rsbNotes.title: 1 Kings 11:23
rsbNotes.text:
11:23 adversary. Formerly Solomon could boast that in his reign there was “neither adversary nor misfortune” (5:4), but now God afflicted him with a succession of enemies.

Hadadezer king of Zobah. On David’s conquest of Hadadezer and Syria, see 2 Sam. 8:3–6; 10:15–19.

rsbNotes.title: 1 Kings 11:24
rsbNotes.text: 11:24 king in Damascus. From his base in Damascus, Rezon persistently caused trouble for Solomon.

rsbNotes.title: 1 Kings 11:26–43
rsbNotes.text: 11:26–43 Jeroboam rebels against Solomon and escapes to Egypt until Solomon’s death.

rsbNotes.title: 1 Kings 11:26
rsbNotes.text:
11:26 Jeroboam the son of Nebat . . . against the king. Whereas Hadad and Rezon are external enemies raised up by God, Jeroboam, an Ephraimite, is an internal foe.

Zeredah. Twenty-one miles east of Joppa in the territory of Ephraim.

rsbNotes.title: 1 Kings 11:27
rsbNotes.text: 11:27 the Millo. See note 9:15.

rsbNotes.title: 1 Kings 11:28
rsbNotes.text: 11:28 over all the forced labor of the house of Joseph. Jeroboam was in charge of the laborers Solomon drafted from the tribes of Ephraim and Manasseh (5:13–16), and was well aware of the resentment these tribes felt toward Solomon (12:4).

rsbNotes.title: 1 Kings 11:29
rsbNotes.text: 11:29 Shilonite. Shiloh was in Ephraim, about twelve miles east of Zeredah.

rsbNotes.title: 1 Kings 11:30
rsbNotes.text: 11:30 tore it into twelve pieces. Ahijah performs a symbolic action, that is, he acts out a parable. Such colorful actions dramatize the reality of the spoken word and God’s intervention in history (cf. 22:11; Is. 20; Jer. 13:1–11). In this case, the torn pieces of Ahijah’s robe illustrate the impending division of the kingdom.

rsbNotes.title: 1 Kings 11:31
rsbNotes.text: 11:31 Take for yourself ten pieces. On behalf of the Lord, Ahijah summons Jeroboam to take ten of the twelve pieces, symbolizing the ten northern tribes over which Jeroboam will shortly become king. As with the earlier rebellions of Hadad and Rezon, Jeroboam’s insurrection is a divine judgment against Solomon.

rsbNotes.title: 1 Kings 11:32
rsbNotes.text: 11:32 one tribe. See note on v. 13.

rsbNotes.title: 1 Kings 11:34
rsbNotes.text: 11:34 I will make him ruler. See note on v. 12.

rsbNotes.title: 1 Kings 11:35
rsbNotes.text: 11:35 out of his son’s hand. That is, from Solomon’s successor, Rehoboam (12:1–24).

rsbNotes.title: 1 Kings 11:36
rsbNotes.text: 11:36 that David my servant may always have a lamp. The metaphor of a lamp signifies the permanence of the Davidic dynasty in the city of Jerusalem (15:4; 2 Sam. 21:17; 2 Kin. 8:19; 2 Chr. 21:7; Ps. 132:17).

rsbNotes.title: 1 Kings 11:37
rsbNotes.text:
11:37 over all that your soul desires. A similar promise is given to David (2 Sam. 3:21).

king over Israel. That is, over the ten northern tribes. During the period of the divided kingdom, the term “Israel” most often designates these ten tribes. “Judah” denotes the domain still ruled by David’s descendants.

rsbNotes.title: 1 Kings 11:38
rsbNotes.text:
11:38 listen to all that I command you. Jeroboam will be subject to the same covenantal stipulations that were operative for Saul, David, and Solomon (2:3, 4 and notes).

I will be with you. These words are an assurance of God’s presence and sustenance (Deut. 31:8; Judg. 2:18; 6:12, 16; 1 Sam. 3:19; 2 Sam. 5:10; 7:9). Ahijah hopes that Jeroboam will be more loyal to the covenant than Solomon.

rsbNotes.title: 1 Kings 11:39
rsbNotes.text: 11:39 but not forever. This phrase looks forward to a restoration of Davidic power. Such a restoration was attempted by Josiah of Judah, but he could not complete it (2 Kin. 22; 23). The prophets also look for a renewal of Davidic rule (Jer. 30:9; Ezek. 34:23; 37:15–28; Hos. 3:5; Amos 9:11). These hopes are fulfilled in Jesus Christ, the Messiah (Matt. 1:1; Mark 1:1).

rsbNotes.title: 1 Kings 11:40
rsbNotes.text: 11:40 Shishak. Shishak was the first king over the twenty-second dynasty and ruled from 945–924 b.c. (14:25, 26). Solomon was married to a daughter of a pharaoh from the twenty-first dynasty (3:1 note).

rsbNotes.title: 1 Kings 11:41
rsbNotes.text: 11:41 the Book of the Acts of Solomon. One of the sources (no longer in existence) used by the writer of 1 and 2 Kings. Other official sources are mentioned in 14:19 and 29.

rsbNotes.title: 1 Kings 11:42
rsbNotes.text: 11:42 forty years. Approximately 970–930 b.c.

rsbNotes.title: 1 Kings 12:1–24
rsbNotes.text: 12:1–24 King Rehoboam’s refusal to listen to the people’s request to lighten their burden sparks secession by the northern tribes. From this point on the northern kingdom is usually referred to as Israel, and the southern kingdom as Judah.

rsbNotes.title: 1 Kings 12:1
rsbNotes.text:
12:1 Shechem. This major Israelite center associated with the renewal of the covenant with the Lord (Josh. 24:1–33) was in northern Ephraim, thirty miles north of Jerusalem.

to make him king. Rehoboam traveled to Shechem to be made king by acclamation (see 1 Sam. 11:15 and the covenant the northern tribes made with David in 2 Sam. 5:1–3). As it turned out, the northern tribes did not accept Rehoboam.

rsbNotes.title: 1 Kings 12:2
rsbNotes.text: 12:2 as soon as Jeroboam . . . heard of it. That is, about the death of Solomon (11:43).

rsbNotes.title: 1 Kings 12:4
rsbNotes.text: 12:4 Your father made our yoke heavy. The expression “yoke” is characteristically used for the oppression of the Israelites by foreign rulers (Lev. 26:13; Deut. 28:48; Is. 9:4; 10:27; 14:25; Jer. 27:8, 11; Ezek. 34:27). Its use here is an indictment of Solomon for imposing harsh labor on his own people (5:13; 9:22; 11:28 and notes).

rsbNotes.title: 1 Kings 12:6
rsbNotes.text: 12:6 the old men. These older and experienced advisers were well acquainted with the traditions of Israel and understood how the monarchy affected the lives of ordinary Israelites.

rsbNotes.title: 1 Kings 12:7
rsbNotes.text: 12:7 If you will be a servant. Though entrusted with power, the Israelite king was to establish justice and so serve both God and His people (Deut. 17:14–20; Ps. 72).

rsbNotes.title: 1 Kings 12:8
rsbNotes.text: 12:8 the young men. These young advisers, like Rehoboam himself, had grown up in the royal court. Apparently they thought that Rehoboam’s privileges were inalienable like those of an oriental monarch.

rsbNotes.title: 1 Kings 12:10
rsbNotes.text: 12:10 My little finger is thicker than my father’s thighs. These words are an arrogant and unwise boast about how much more oppressive Rehoboam’s yoke will be than his father’s (v. 11).

rsbNotes.title: 1 Kings 12:15
rsbNotes.text: 12:15 by the Lord. The writer does not mention God’s agency in order to excuse Rehoboam’s foolishness. God is using Rehoboam’s misguided actions as an instrument for fulfilling Ahijah’s prophecy (11:31–39).

rsbNotes.title: 1 Kings 12:16
rsbNotes.text: 12:16 Look now to your own house, David. The northern tribes secede from Judah and from the authority of David’s descendants. For an identical taunt against David himself, see 2 Sam. 20:1.

rsbNotes.title: 1 Kings 12:17
rsbNotes.text: 12:17 people of Israel. That is, members of the northern tribes who had settled in the south.

rsbNotes.title: 1 Kings 12:18
rsbNotes.text:
12:18 Adoram. Rehoboam unwisely sent out the chief of forced labor to quell the uprising (4:6; 5:14, where the name is spelled “Adoniram”).

all Israel. That is, representatives of the northern tribes (12:1).

rsbNotes.title: 1 Kings 12:19
rsbNotes.text: 12:19 to this day. See 8:8 note.
